entry.title: TabRenderer - Quick preview for your tabular data
entry.content:
I recently learned from a friend that Github renders tabular data (.csv and .tsv) as interactive table, which is really neat. However, it won’t work if there’s a mismatched column or illegal quoting so I quickly built a tabrenderer to help people preview their data before pushing them to Github. At first, I was going to use JavaScript to parse the data but was afraid that it will not work the same way as Github’s parser. After browsing their repos, I thought it’s very likely that they use Ruby to do this given how often they use Ruby for their own projects. Besides, Ruby has its built-in class CSV that takes care of almost everything.

So far, tabrenderer notifies users of errors that prevent the parser to work such as illegal quoting. It will jump to the row that has such errors but will not scream if there’s a mismatched column (it will be obvious to the users though to see some rows don’t have columns). The users can either upload their file or simply type the data in the text box.

entry.title: Thirsty? Google map for a drinking fountain
entry.content:
Or you can head over to Vancouver Fountain Finder and search for the nearest drinking fountain in Vancouver, BC.

This is a small project I built during the school break to learn Node.js. I have always wanted to learn Node.js and use Google Maps API so I tried to think of features that will let me learn new things as much as possible. Before this, I also built a simple timer just to get started with Node.js and become familiar with Knockout.js and Semantic-UI. I guess Semantic-UI is still relatively new so I still prefer Bootstrap or maybe I am just biased… Anyway, a timer because I saw my Math teacher struggling with the online stopwatch before the exam… And the ads were quite distracting…

Just a quick update since now I’m back to school. Back to studying.

entry.title: Mozilla Jaw's Puzzle
entry.content:
I’m actually a little late for this Jaw’s programming puzzle, which I only discovered yesterday from reading a blog written by a Mozilla employee. If I had seen this post a bit earlier, I might even have had a chance to work for them since I solved it! yay.

(btw, if you love solving programming problems, please take a moment to go through the puzzle (it’s really worth it) but note that this post contains SPOILERS.)

At first, I was a bit unsure about the complicated-and-low-level-looking javascript in the source code:

\x6E\x20\x50\x72\x6F\x78\x79\x20\x6F\x62\x6A\x65\x63\x74\x20\x61\x6E\x64\x20\x63\x61\x6C\x6C\x20\x76\x65\x72\x69\x66\x79\x20\x77\x69\x74\x68\x20\x69\x74\x2E","\x74\x65\x78\x74\x43\x6F\x6E\x74\x65\x6E\x74","\x66\x69\x6E\x50","\x69\x6E\x73\x65\x72\x74\x42\x65\x66\x6F\x72\x65","\x70\x61\x72\x65\x6E\x74\x4E\x6F\x64\x65","\x33","\x66\x69\x72\x65\x66\x6F\x78","\x78\x6F\x66\x65\x72\x69\x66","\x74\x68\x75\x6E\x64\x65\x72\x62\x69\x72\x64","\x64\x72\x69\x62\x72\x65\x64\x6E\x75\x68\x74","\x6D\x6F\x7A\x69\x6C\x6C\x61","\x61\x6C\x6C\x69\x7A\x6F\x6D","\x6E\x70\x64\x2F\x62\x6D\x6D\x6A\x7B\x70\x6E\x41\x53\x46\x4F\x4F\x4A\x58\x53\x46\x4F\x4F\x4A\x58\x2C\x74\x78\x62\x6B","\x47\x72\x65\x61\x74\x20\x6A\x6F\x62\x21\x20\x54\x68\x65\x20\x65\x6D\x61\x69\x6C\x20\x61\x64\x64\x72\x65\x73\x73\x20\x68\x61\x73\x20\x62\x65\x65\x6E\x20\x75\x70\x64\x61\x74\x65\x64\x20\x74\x6F\x20\x73\x68\x6F\x77\x20\x79\x6F\x75\x72\x20\x74\x72\x75\x65\x20\x31\x33\x33\x37\x2D\x6E\x65\x73\x73\x2E\x20\x45\x76\x65\x72\x20\x73\x65\x65\x20\x61\x20\x77\x65\x62\x70\x61\x67\x65\x20\x69\x6E\x20\x33\x44\x20\x62\x65\x66\x6F\x72\x65\x3F\x20\x54\x69\x6C\x74\x20\x74\x68\x65\x20\x70\x61\x67\x65\x20\x74\x6F\x20\x66\x69\x6E\x64\x20\x77\x68\x61\x74\x20\x79\x6F\x75\x20\x63\x61\x6E\x20\x70\x75\x74\x20\x61\x73\x20\x79\x6F\x75\x72\x20\x73\x75\x62\x6A\x65\x63\x74\x20\x6F\x66\x20\x74\x68\x65\x20\x65\x6D\x61\x69\x6C\x20\x3A\x29","\x77\x72\x61\x70\x70\x65\x72","\x64\x69\x73\x70\x6C\x61\x79","\x73\x74\x79\x6C\x65","\x62\x6C\x6F\x63\x6B"];var _0x1k(_0x8543x8){if(_0x8543x8!=_0x9827[14]&&_0x8543x8!=_0x9827[13]&&_0x8543x8!=_0x9827[15]){return ;} ;var _0x8543x9=_0x9827[16];var _0x8543xa,_0x8543xb;for(var _0x8543xc in _0x8543x8){_0x8543x9+=String[_0x9827[18]](_0x8543x8[_0x8543xc][_0x9827[17]](0)-1);} ;_0x1d[_0x9827[19]](_0x8543x9,0,10);if(++_0x1e==2){var _0x8543xd=_0x1a[_0x9827[21]](_0x9827[20]);var _0x8543xe=[_0x9827[22]][0];_0x8543xd[_0x9827[23]]=_0x8543xe;_0x8543xa=_0x1a[_0x9827[0]](_0x9827[24]);_0x8543xa[_0x9827[26]][_0x9827[25]](_0x8543xd,_0x8543xa);_0x1b[_0x9827[23]]=_0x9827[27];} ;} _0x8543x11=[_0x9827[28],_0x9827[29],_0x9827[30],_0x9827[31],_0x9827[32],_0x9827[33]];if(_0x8543x10[_0x8543x11[0]]==_0x8543x11[1]&&_0x8543x10[_0x8543x11[2]]==_0x8543x11[3]&&_0x8543x10[_0x8543x11[4]]==_0x8543x11[5]){_0x1c[_0x9827[5]]=_0x9827[6];_0x1c[_0x9827[7]]=_0x9827[8];_0x1d[_0x9827[9]]=_0x9827[10];_0x1d[_0x9827[11]]=_0x9827[12];_0x1k(_0x8543x10[_0x9827[34]]);var _0x8543xd=_0x1a[_0x9827[21]](_0x9827[20]);_0xabb2=[_0x9827[35]];_0x8543xd[_0x9827[23]]=_0xabb2[0];_0xabb3=_0x1a[_0x9827[0]](_0x9827[36]);_0xabb3[_0x9827[26]][_0x9827[25]](_0x8543xd,_0xabb3);_0xabb3[_0x9827[38]][_0x9827[37]]=_0x9827[39];} ;} ;

Yeah, but it’s okay, firebug will make life much easier for us. So first thing we need to do is to find out what this javascript code does. It looks like the variable _0x9827 holds some sort of information, so let’s check it out in the DOM: Now expand it: Sweet! Now I have some clue:

“Step 2. There is a function defined in this page called verify(). It takes one argument which is a proxy object. The proxy object needs to return the reversed string of the requested property name. For example, obj.foo should return ‘oof’. To complete step 2, create your own Proxy object and call verify with it.”

But I didn’t know what a proxy object was so for this one Google is the best answer. I found an example of creating a proxy object:

```javascript var p = Proxy.create({ get: function(proxy, name) {

return 'Hello, '+ name;

} });

document.write(p.World); // should print ‘Hello, World’ ```

Easy enough, now all I need to do is create my own proxy that reverses the string of the requested property name, then call the verify() function with it:

``` var proxy = Proxy.create({ get: function(proxy, name) {

return name.split("").reverse().join("");

} }); verify(proxy); ```

Then put the snippet in the javascript source code using firebug (in the HTML section, right click on the javascript line then select “Edit HTML”): And it works! Ok cool, the answer is: jaws+WINNERWINNER@mozilla.com

But there’s one more bonus puzzle:

Ever see a webpage in 3D before? Tilt the page to find what you can put as your subject of the email :)

Oh, firefox has the new 3D feature, which is extremely cool. To activate it, right click on the page and select “Inspect Element” (and not “Inspect Element with Firebug”). You will see at the bottom of your browser there’s a button “3D View”, click on it. (If your browser complains, it’s probably because you don’t have the Tilt add-on installed). Play around, tilt the page, zoom it in and out to see the magic:

1337 !

entry.title: Chess
entry.content:
Want to play some chess? Here is a chess board for you written in HTML5 using the drag and drop feature. Make sure your browser supports HTML5. Now drag away!

UPDATE: Now the chess rules are enforced. It won’t move unless you follow the rules :)

♜ ♞ ♝ ♛ ♚ ♝ ♞ ♜
♟ ♟ ♟ ♟ ♟ ♟ ♟ ♟
               
               
               
               
♙ ♙ ♙ ♙ ♙ ♙ ♙ ♙
♖ ♘ ♗ ♕ ♔ ♗ ♘ ♖

BONUS: HTML localStorage and contentEditable. Features that allow you to edit a page’s section on the browser and store your scribbles on the client-side database:

Click "clear local storage" if you don't want your notes to be remembered (If your notes are not remembered, it means your browser has localStorage turned off or doesn't support it unfortunately)
